Weekly Brief

AI x PMM Weekly Brief ‚Äî Feb 8, 2026

February 8, 2026 ‚Ä¢ Curated by Chris O'Hara

Executive Summary: This was the week AI stopped being a "future of marketing" story and became a "present tense disruption" story. Anthropic's Cowork plugins triggered a $285 billion stock selloff across software, financial services, and data companies ‚Äî a wake-up call that AI isn't just augmenting knowledge work, it's threatening to replace entire categories of it.

Meanwhile, OpenAI is discovering that monetizing AI through advertising is harder than it looks, and a new report reveals that AI hallucinations are creating real brand risks for marketers who've embedded these tools into their workflows without guardrails.

The bottom line for PMMs: The hype cycle is over. We're now in the accountability phase ‚Äî where AI's limitations matter as much as its capabilities, and your ability to use these tools responsibly becomes a competitive advantage.

üìâ The $285 Billion Wake-Up Call

Anthropic released industry-specific plugins for its Cowork tool ‚Äî including legal, finance, sales, and marketing modules ‚Äî and the market panicked. Software stocks across Europe and the US cratered as investors realized these AI assistants could replace specialized research, analysis, and content tools.

Why it matters for PMMs: The tools that help you (competitive intel platforms, research databases, content suites) are also the tools at risk. If an AI can do 80% of what a $50K/year software license does, budget conversations are coming. PMMs need to be the ones leading that conversation, not reacting to it.

Read more: Bloomberg | The Guardian

üéØ OpenAI's Advertising Problem

Reuters reported that only 2% of ChatGPT prompts involve purchasable products ‚Äî a major headache for OpenAI's ad monetization plans. Google's AI Overviews show ads in just 0.1% of results. Turns out, people use AI assistants for thinking, not shopping.

PMM takeaway: AI chat interfaces are attention magnets but intent deserts. Don't rush to "advertise in AI" without understanding the fundamental difference between search intent and conversational exploration. The playbook hasn't been written yet.

Read more: Reuters

‚ö†Ô∏è AI Hallucinations: The Marketing Risk No One's Measuring

NP Digital dropped a report showing AI inaccuracies are "widespread" in marketing workflows. When your AI writes copy with made-up stats, cites nonexistent sources, or hallucinates product features ‚Äî that's not just embarrassing, it's a brand trust issue.

The fix: Treat AI output like you'd treat a junior hire's first draft. Verify, edit, fact-check. The PMMs who build verification workflows into their AI processes will avoid the landmines others are stepping on.

Read more: Globe Newswire

üìã IAB's AI Transparency Framework

The IAB released the industry's first AI Transparency and Disclosure Framework for advertising ‚Äî guidelines for when and how to disclose AI use in creative, targeting, and content. It's voluntary for now, but smart brands are adopting it preemptively.

Why PMMs should care: Transparency requirements are coming, whether through regulation or consumer pressure. Getting ahead of disclosure standards now ‚Äî especially for AI-generated content ‚Äî builds trust and avoids future scrambles.

Read more: IAB Framework

üèà Super Bowl Ad Drama: Anthropic vs OpenAI

Both AI giants are reportedly battling for Super Bowl airtime. The symbolism isn't subtle ‚Äî AI companies are now playing the brand awareness game that consumer tech giants have dominated for decades. Expect more mainstream AI advertising as the race for consumer mindshare heats up.

For PMMs: Watch how these companies position themselves to mainstream audiences. The messaging frameworks they're testing at scale will influence how enterprises talk about AI for the next year.

üìä 2026 AI Marketing Trends: Operating Models Over Tools

A Gutenberg report nailed something important: the 2026 trends aren't about new tools ‚Äî they're about new operating models. Pod-based execution, predictive strategy, intent-led personalization, and system-based creative production are replacing the "let's try this AI tool" experimentation phase.

Translation: Stop collecting AI tools and start designing AI-native workflows. The PMMs who figure out how AI changes how they work (not just what tools they use) will outperform those still treating AI as a feature, not an infrastructure shift.

Read more: The Gutenberg

üìå TL;DR for PMMs

  1. Anthropic's Cowork plugins triggered a $285B selloff ‚Äî the market is pricing in AI replacement risk across knowledge work
  2. AI advertising is harder than expected ‚Äî only 2% of ChatGPT prompts involve shopping intent
  3. AI hallucinations are a brand risk ‚Äî build verification into your workflows now
  4. IAB released transparency guidelines ‚Äî get ahead of disclosure requirements
  5. Operating models matter more than tools ‚Äî stop collecting, start restructuring

This week's winning move: Audit your AI workflows for accuracy risks before someone else finds the errors. The brands that treat AI output as "draft, not done" will avoid the trust hits coming for those who don't.
